origin: Old English temprian  ‘bring something into the required condition by mixing it with something else’, from Latin temperare ‘mingle, restrain’. Sense development was probably influenced by Old French temprer ‘to temper, moderate’. The noun originally denoted a proportionate mixture of elements or qualities, also the combination of the four bodily humours, believed in medieval times to be the basis of temperament, hence temper (sense 1 of the noun) (late Middle English). Compare with temperament.

definitions.example: he tripped over his cat

definitions.definition: walk, run, or dance with quick light steps.
definitions.example: they tripped up the terrace steps

definitions.definition: activate (a mechanism), especially by contact with a switch, catch, or other electrical device.
definitions.example: somebody tripped the alarm

definitions.definition: release and raise (an anchor) from the seabed by means of a cable.
experience hallucinations induced by taking a psychedelic drug, especially LSD.
definitions.example: a couple of boys were tripping

definitions.definition: go on a short journey.
definitions.example: when tripping through the Yukon take some time to explore our museums
